Award.AwardTitle: Developing Structure-Property Relationships for Electronic Structure and Dynamics at Organic Semiconductor Interfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms A program of the National Science Foundation, Professor Oliver Monti of the University of Arizona is studying organic molecules on metal surfaces, with a specific focus on how the structure of the molecules and the metal influences the rate at which electrons can be transferred from the metal surface to the molecule (and vice versa).  Professor Monti's research group uses several experimental techniques in this investigation, including scanning tunneling microscopy (STM), which can image individual atoms and molecules, and photoelectron spectroscopy, which uses intense laser light to eject electrons from the sample, and reveals how strongly electrons are bound to either the molecule or the surface.   This electrons transfer from metal surface to molecule must be carefully controlled for improved catalysis, new sensor technologies and novel approaches to energy conversion.

This project develops a systematic and fundamental understanding of the interplay of electronic structure, self-assembly and carrier dynamics at organic semiconductor / metal interfaces. Professor Monti combines atomically resolved scanning tunneling microscopy with momentum- and time-resolved photoelectron spectroscopy of interfaces with systematically varied molecular and surface electronic structure to enable predictive tailoring of charge flow across interfaces. Charge-transfer across interfaces constitutes a central process in heterogeneous catalysis, electrochemistry and novel organic electronic technologies. Beyond training the next generation of scientists in Chemistry, Professor Monti and his students are developing and disseminating a database of organic semiconductors which links key molecular properties to device performance. This database is also used in active engagement classroom activities at The University of Arizona to develop the concept of structure-property relationships within the General Chemistry curriculum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: In this project, Monti and coworkers have investigated how the interface between organic semiconductors and electrodes can be tailored in order to facailiate efficient charge-transfer across the interface. The ability to enable fast and low-loss charge-transfer across such interfaces is of broad relevance in electrochemistry, catalysis, and for novel devices that combine dye-like molecules with metallic electrodes to create ultrathin light-emitting diodes, solar cells, transistors or spin-selective devices for storage and memory. During the award period, the researchers investigated the role of molecular structure and found that it is possible to direct self-assembly into massively nanostructured thin films with profoundly different electronic properties depending on molecular adsorption geometry, tuned by minor chemical structural differences. Some of these experiments were interpreted and understood in collaboration with theorists in Austria. The researchers also investigated new avenues to nanostructure the electrode surface to guide self-assembly. By using extremely sensitive probes with atomic resolution they were able to show that creating nanoscale stripes on the electrode surface can indeed influence both molecular adsorption geometry and the resulting electronic structure, though no large-scale self-assembly was achieved. The charge-carrier dynamics themselves were investigated using novel x-ray spectroscopic approaches that were able to resolve directional charge-transfer at attosecond time-scales. The project resulted in 9 published manuscripts with one more in preparation, and the PI and his students have given 22 invited and 10 contributed talks.

Broader Impact: The grant supported graduate students at different stages of their PhD career. All of them have won prizes at Arizona in recognition of their excellence in research. One of them is now employed in the private sector, two are postdoctoral scholars in National Labs, and three are still pursuing their PhD. In addition, the grant has supported a range of undergraduate students, several of whom are from underrepresented and sociioeconomically disadvantaged groups. One of them is now pursuing a PhD at Stony Brook Unviersity, and several others are still finishing their undergraduate degree. As part of their broader impacts, the research group also developed a database of molecular properties that will be made available to the public.
